Name_5: CISA: Prepare now for quantum computers not when hackers use them
Text_5:
Although quantum computing is not commercially available CISA (Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency) urges organizations to prepare for the dawn of this new age which is expected to bring groundbreaking changes in cryptography and how we protect our secrets.

The agency published a paper earlier in the week calling for leaders to start preparing for the migration to stronger secret guarding systems exploring risk mitigation methods and participating in developing new standards.

Race to Quantum supremacy

Quantum computers are systems that harness quantum mechanics to perform much more powerful computations than are available today on systems that rely on binary (0 1) computations.

Experts in the field widely accept that the currently experimental quantum computers will achieve superiority over conventional systems by the end of the decade and will quickly render them obsolete with subsequent capability leaps.

This is expected to revolutionize research solve long-standing mathematical problems perform higher-level physics simulations and accelerate the development of artificial intelligence models.

The main negative implication of this quantum computing concerns the cryptography of secrets a fundamental element of information security.

Cryptographic schemes that are today considered secure will be cracked in mere seconds by quantum computers leaving persons companies and entire countries powerless against the computing supremacy of their adversaries.

“When quantum computers reach higher levels of computing power and speed they will be capable of breaking public key cryptography threatening the security of business transactions secure communications digital signatures and customer information” explains CISA.

This could threaten data in transit relating to top-secret communications banking operations military operations government meetings critical industrial processes and more.

Yesterday China's Baidu introduced “Qian Shi” an industry-level quantum supercomputer capable of achieving stable performance at 10 quantum bits of power.

Baidu also stated that it recently completed the design of a 36-qubit superconducting quantum chip with couplers which threatens to surpass the strength of the leading American quantum machine IonQ Aria which tops at 20 qubits.

Other companies in the race for quantum supremacy are Intel IBM Microsoft and Google all competing to advance the field.

Preparing for the new age

Research into quantum-secure encryption algorithms is already underway and NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) plans to publish official guidelines on the topic by the end of 2024.

Until then CISA recommends that all stakeholders follow the “post-quantum cryptography roadmap” which can be summarized in the following:

CEOs should increase their engagement with post-quantum standards developing organizations.

Organizations should inventory the most sensitive and critical datasets that must be secured for an extended amount of time.

Organizations should conduct an inventory of all the systems using cryptographic technologies for any function to facilitate a smooth transition in the future.

Cybersecurity officials within organizations should identify acquisition cybersecurity and data security standards that will require updating to reflect post-quantum requirements.

Organizations should identify where and for what purpose public key cryptography is being used and mark those systems as quantum vulnerable.

Prioritize one system over another for cryptographic transition based on the organization’s functions goals and needs.

Using the inventory and prioritization information organizations should develop a plan for systems transitions upon publication of the new post-quantum cryptographic standard.

“Do not wait until the quantum computers are in use by our adversaries to act. Early preparations will ensure a smooth migration to the post-quantum cryptography standard once it is available” concludes the agency.

Name: Illumina
Name_1: L’Amerigo Vespucci torna a Malta dopo 11 anni e illumina il “Grand Harbour” con il Trico ...
Text_1:
MeteoWeb

L’Amerigo Vespucci considerata “la nave più bella del mondo” ha fatto tappa nel porto di Malta ben 11 anni dopo l’ultima volta. Il maestoso veliero della Marina Militare italiana è arrivato a Malta venerdì 26 agosto proveniente da Trapani e ha ormeggiato al Grand Harbour di La Valletta dov’è rimasta due giorni fino ad oggi quando è ripartita poco fa verso l’Italia diretta in Puglia.

A bordo ci sono 143 allievi della prima classe dell’Accademia Navale di Livorno di cui 13 stranieri provenienti dai 6 Paesi esteri: il 3 settembre a Taranto concluderanno il tirocinio pratico che ha avuto inizio i primi di luglio a Livorno dove si è svolto il loro “Battesimo del mare” lungo un tour estivo che li ha portati a Palermo Tunisi Algeri Lisbona Casablanca Cadige Trapani Malta appunto e adesso Manfredonia e infine Taranto.

Durante la sosta a Malta gli allievi hanno avuto la possibilità di visitare la città e accogliere ospiti a bordo durante le visite che hanno avuto un grande successo nella giornata di ieri conclusa poi con una serata di discoteca riservata agli allievi che hanno ballato fino a mezzanotte nell’area di poppa.

L’Amerigo Vespucci oggi guidata dal Comandante Massimiliano Siragusa è considerata la “nave più bella del mondo” per la straordinarietà delle opere d’arte che la adornano frutto dell’ingegno italiano: rappresenta un motivo d’orgoglio per gli appassionati italiani di mare e di navigazione anche perché rappresenta la Marina e dopo il tramonto illumina sempre i suoi tre alberi con la bandiera Tricolore.

Iscrivendoti dichiari di aver preso visione delle condizioni generali del servizio.
Name_2: Satelliti o meteore? Cosa sono quelle luci nel cielo e come riconoscerle
Text_2: Restando ancora nell’atmosfera terrestre c’è un tipo di oggetto che ultimamente si vede spesso volare soprattutto in corrispondenza di alcune festività. Sono le lanterne volanti o mongolfiere di carta piccoli sacchetti di carta di riso con una candela a produrre il calore necessario per scaldare l’aria interna e farle volare. Originarie di alcune culture dell'estremo oriente queste lanterne sono piuttosto semplici da riconoscere. Il loro colore in genere è rossiccio e il loro movimento spesso è molto lento e piuttosto verticale anche se seguendo la direzione e la velocità dei venti può capitare di vederle sbandare all’improvviso. Queste lanterne normalmente ridiscendono altrettanto lentamente mano mano che la candela si consuma ma talvolta arrivano a terra ancora accese innescando incendi motivo per cui i regolamenti si stanno irrigidendo sul loro utilizzo.
Name_3: Sbarca 'Pavani Group' "Assunzioni in vista"
Text_3:
Per cogliere la continuità aziendale bisogna attendere la sera quando il prato disseminato di piante si illumina di colori che danno l’immagine di un bosco incantato. Ma è l’unico elemento che segna il passaggio di testimone tra vecchio e nuovo. Da lunedì i cancelli dello stabilimento un tempo sede della Martini Luce di Concordia riapriranno per accogliere d’ora in poi la Pavani Group società mantovana fondata da Maurizio Pavani che ne ha acquistato il marchio e la proprietà. Da mesi le ditte incaricate erano al lavoro per adeguare gli immobili del vecchio complesso industriale alle esigenze produttive della nuova proprietà. "Il marchio Martini – ci dice Maurizio Pavani il titolare della omonima azienda che realizza da 25 anni impianti di segnalamento ferroviario e che si trasferisce dalla originaria sede nel mantovano – lo abbiamo mantenuto poiché confluisce nella parte illuminotecnica che facciamo per conto di Rete Ferroviaria Italiana con cui abbiamo iniziato approcci e presentato prodotti tuttora in corso di omologazione".

Nel mese di agosto poi terminate le opere murarie ed impiantistiche è stata portata a compimento la migrazione di tutta la parte informatica e della strumentazione degli uffici dalla vecchia sede. Ora Pavani Group è pronta per essere ripiantata nel Modenese e per la sua rinascita che poggia soprattutto sulla partenza dei bandi previsti dal Pnrr per l’ammodernamento della mobilità su rotaia in Italia nonché sui profondi cambiamenti che hanno segnato il mondo ferroviario non più dominato da impianti elettromeccanici. Nella nuova azienda un reparto adibito a Museo mostrerà i cambiamenti intervenuti per quanto riguarda i sistemi di segnalamento ferroviario. "Oggi – spiega Pavani - si parla di impianti digitali il cui know-how è posseduto solo dalle grandi multinazionali con le quali comunque noi lavoriamo da anni". E’ guardando al futuro che Pavani Group ha deciso di spostare la sua sede e ampliarsi acquisendo la proprietà di questa vasta area di oltre 30.000 mq quindicimila dei quali coperti posti all’incrocio tra via per Mirandola e via Grandi in grado di soddisfare le esigenze di una impresa destinata a crescere non solo come fatturato ma anche come maestranze. "Oggi siamo 86 – afferma Pavani – ma con le prospettive aperte dai fondi del Pnrr se chiudiamo le trattative avviate con le multinazionali partecipanti ai bandi la nostra azienda necessiterà di inserire 40-50 nuovi dipendenti. E per questo ci siamo organizzati per avere una struttura ampia dotata anche di aula magna per poter fare formazione". L’inaugurazione sarà il 23 settembre presente il presidente della Regione Stefano Bonaccini ma il cammino verso il futuro di Pavani Group inizia domani.

Alberto Greco
Name_4: Scatti del maltempo davanti all'Elba
Text_4:
Le foto postate sui social hanno attirato centinaia di commenti. Permane l'allerta meteo per tutta la giornata di oggi

ISOLA D'ELBA — Allerta meteo in corso per pioggia e temporali anche all'isola d'Elba per tutta la giornata di oggi.

Per il momento i temporali hanno lambito da lontano la costa di Portoferraio e comunque nonostante l'allerta meteo numerose persone oggi si sono ugualmente recate nelle spiagge dell'isola.

Sul gruppo Facebook Isola d’Elba info curiosità vacanze e foto e su alcuni profili sono state pubblicate varie immagini del temporale visto in lontananza.

Ecco qua sotto alcuni scatti.

Foto di Sara Nojoum

Foto di Stefano Terranova

Foto di Maria Teresa Grassi
Name_5: Alberobello i trulli si vestono di luci e arte per il Light festival: c'è tempo fino al 4 settembre
Text_5:
Ritorno alla luce. In coda all'estate Alberobello ritrova il suo LiFe - Light festival che fino a domenica 4 settembre illumina alcuni dei suoi scorci più emblematici grazie alle creazioni di una serie di artisti internazionali. È la ripresa dopo il lungo fermo imposto dall'emergenza sanitaria legata alla pandemia da Covid-19 e le luci che ogni sera dal tramonto a mezzanotte (a partire dalle 21) animeranno la cittadina riconosciuta patrimonio dell'Unesco - merito dei suoi unici e inconfondibili trulli - hanno più di un significato.

Hanno valore artistico prima di tutto ma sono anche espressione di rinascita e "segno di speranza" come dice Luca Agnani. Proprio lui è uno dei protagonisti della manifestazione organizzata dall'associazione di promozione sociale Lightcones: è un visual designer e artista multimediale originario del Maceratese con i suoi esperimenti visuali rivisita spesso opere moderne e nella sua carriera è riuscito a dare nuova vita e prospettiva a importanti e noti palazzi in Italia e all'estero fra cui la Farnesina a Roma il Duomo di Monza l'Istituto italiano di cultura di Madrid.

Quello di Agnani ad Alberobello è un ritorno perché partecipa al Light Festival con Metamorphosis un progetto di videomapping sulla basilica dei Santi Medici già presentato nel 2019.

La proiezione luminosa sulla basilica dei Santi medici (foto di Cosmo Laera)

"È un lavoro che si attiene molto all'architettura - dice lo stesso Agnani - Ho scomposto e ricomposto colorato e usato l'architettura stessa per creare gli effetti". Il suo intervento ha una durata di circa sette minuti e sarà ripetuto per tutta la serata in ogni sera del festival. Ha quasi il sapore di un cerchio che si chiude di un discorso che riprende lì dove era stato interrotto ed è solo uno di quelli in programma. L'edizione 2022 di LiFe non a caso si chiama 'Reloaded' e punta a richiamare ad Alberobello alcuni degli artisti che sono già stati ospiti e le cui opere hanno avuto un grande riscontro da parte del pubblico.

Le installazioni quest'anno sono quindi cinque e si sviluppano oltre che sulla facciata della basilica anche al Trullo Sovrano alla chiesa a trullo di Sant'Antonio e all'interno del nuovo edificio sorto al posto dell'ex mercato coperto di largo Martellotta "in un percorso ideale - fanno sapere gli organizzatori - che va dal Trullo Sovrano alla chiesa di Sant'Antonio passando per il centro cittadino e il rione Monti".

Sono varie per tematiche anche le declinazioni che gli artisti hanno dato ai loro interventi e quindi gli stessi ideatori Lightcones occupano l'esterno del Trullo Sovrano con due diversi lavori: Quintessenza e The Pantheon of rock riuscendo a tenere in sequenza filosofia e musica contemporanea. Quintessenza infatti prende le mosse da Platone dando vita a un gioco di luci e suoni: "Platone nell'opera Timeo mentre racconta le origini e il funzionamento del cosmo formula l'ipotesi che la materia sia composta da quattro particelle aventi la forma dei primi quattro poliedri regolari - fanno sapere da LiFe - corrispondenti ai quattro elementi tradizionali (Terra Acqua Aria Fuoco) ai quali si aggiunge il concetto di Quintessenza che racchiude il quinto elemento l'Universo".

Le installazioni luminose sulla basilica dei Santi medici (foto di Cosmo Laera)

Questo progetto si alternerà a The Pantheon of rock "un intimo tributo" - sempre a firma Lightcones - alla musica e ad alcuni dei suoi protagonisti "trasformati in divinità di una cosmogonia rock in un gioco onirico e psichedelico". Riprende lo stesso discorso interrotto e anzi va a scavare nella memoria l'installazione Van Gogh reloaded: il tema fu presentato per la prima volta nel 2015 e stavolta Lightcones propone una rielaborazione del noto dipinto Notte stellata del pittore olandese sulla chiesa di Sant'Antonio l'unica a forma di trullo.

Dalla Slovenia infine arrivano a completare il quadro di Light Festival 2022 le artiste Natalija R. Crnec e Nina Šulin: prendono posto a Casa Alberobello (ex mercato coperto di via Martellotta) e vi fanno esplodere Coexistence un'installazione che punta sulle forme organiche fluttuanti "simili a corpi di animali avvolti da veli neri - precisano dall'organizzazione della manifestazione - recanti tracce fluorescenti che attribuiscono una forma visiva di movimento e di respiro costante che li porta alla vita nella loro essenza di base e lo spettatore riconosce in essi embrioni animali e umani".

Anche quello di Crncec e Šulin è un ritorno ad Alberobello dopo che nell'edizione 2017 incantarono il pubblico con InParallel. Stavolta insistono sul concetto di coesistenze proponendo l'esito di un progetto nato da un lungo e paziente lavoro manuale e che promette di sedurre il visitatore e risucchiarlo seguendo la possibilità di "delineare l'esperienza eccessiva della (co)esistenza e (co)creazione attraverso un gioco di addensamento e avvicinamento". Info alberobellolightfestival.com.

Name: Intel
Name_1: Intel Details Inner Workings of XeSS
Text_1:
Intel released an explainer video for its upcoming XeSS AI upscaling technology and showcased how the tech works on its nearly ready for public release Arc Alchemist GPUs. It used the fastest Arc A770 for the demonstrations though it's difficult to say how the performance will stack up against the best graphics cards based on the limited performance details shown.



If you're at all familiar with Nvidia's DLSS which has been around for four years now in various incarnations the video should spark a keen sense of Deja Vu. Tom Petersen who formerly worked for Nvidia and gave some of the old DLSS presentations walks through the XeSS fundamentals. Long story short XeSS sounds very much like a mirrored version of Nvidia's DLSS except it's designed to work with Intel's deep learning XMX cores rather than Nvidia's tensor cores. The tech can also work with other GPUs however using DP4a mode which might make it an interesting alternative to AMD's FSR 2.0 upscaler.



In the demos shown by Intel XeSS looked to be working well. Of course it's difficult to say for sure when the source video is a 1080p compressed version of the actual content but we'll save detailed image quality comparisons for another time. Performance gains look to be similar to what we've seen with DLSS with over a 100% frame rate boost in some situations when using XeSS Performance mode.

How It Works

If you already know how DLSS works Intel's solution is largely the same but with some minor tweaks. XeSS is an AI accelerated resolution upscaling algorithm designed to increase frame rates in video games.



It starts with training the first step in most deep learning algorithms. The AI network takes lower resolution sample frames from a game and processes them generating what should be upscaled output images. Then the network compares the results against the desired target image and back propagates weight adjustments to try and correct any "errors." At first the resulting images won't look very good but the AI algorithm slowly learns from its mistakes. After thousands (or more) of training images the network eventually converges toward ideal weights that will "magically" generate the desired results.



Once the algorithm has been fully trained using samples from lots of different games it can in theory take any image input from any video game and upscale it almost perfectly. As with DLSS (and FSR 2.0) the XeSS algorithm also takes on the role of anti-aliasing and replaces classical solutions like temporal AA.

(Image credit: Intel)

Again nothing so far is particularly noteworthy. DLSS and FSR 2.0 and even standard temporal AA algorithms have a lot of the same core functionality — minus the AI stuff for FSR and TAA. Games will integrate XeSS into their rendering pipeline typically after the main render and initial effects are done but before post processing effects and GUI/HUD elements are drawn. That way the UI stays sharp while the difficult task of 3D rendering gets to run at a lower resolution.



XeSS operates on Intel's Arc XMX cores but it can also run on other GPUs in a slightly different mode. DP4a instructions are basically four INT8 (8-bit integer) calculations done using a single 32-bit register what you'd typically have access to via a GPU shader core. XMX cores meanwhile natively support INT8 and can operate on 128 values at once.



That might seem very lopsided but as an example an Arc A380 has 1024 shader cores that could each do four INT8 operations at the same time. Alternatively the A380 has 128 MXM units that can each do 128 INT8 operations. That makes the MXM throughput four times faster than the DP4a throughput but apparently DP4a mode should still be sufficient for some level of XeSS goodness.



Note that DP4a appears to use a different trained network one that's perhaps less computationally intensive. How that will translate into real-world performance and image quality remains to be seen and it sounds like game developers will need to explicitly include support for both XMX and DP4a modes if they want to support non-Arc GPUs.

Image 1 of 3 (Image credit: Intel) (Image credit: Intel) (Image credit: Intel)

Intel XeSS Performance Expectations

Intel showed off a couple of gaming tests running XeSS including a development build of Shadow of the Tomb Raider and a new 3DMark benchmark specifically made for XeSS. It also showed brief clips of Arcadegeddon Redout II Ghostwire Tokyo The DioField Chronicle Chivalry II Naraka Bladepoint and Super People running with and without XeSS at the end of the video. Note that Intel has never shown XeSS running in DP4a mode which is something we still want to see.



In Shadow of the Tomb Raider running on an Arc A770 graphics card at 2560x1440 with nearly maxed out settings including ray traced shadows XeSS provided anywhere from about a 25% performance boost on the Ultra Quality setting up to a more than a 100% to frame rates at using the Performance setting. The Quality and Balanced settings go for a middle ground and improved performance by around 50% and 75% respectively.



Those gains will naturally vary by the game engine settings and base performance. The more demanding the game and the lower the framerate the more beneficial XeSS will likely be. Using the Performance mode Intel showed typical gains of anywhere from 40% to 110% at 1440p while the Balanced mode delivered improvements ranging from about 25% to as much as 75%.

Image 1 of 2 (Image credit: Intel) (Image credit: Intel)

3DMark will also be adding an Intel XeSS Feature Test for its Advanced edition which includes a benchmark mode as well as a Frame Inspector that allows users to look at images of the benchmark zooming in to check the visual quality differences. It looks a lot easier to use than Nvidia's ICAT utility though of course it's also limited to providing frames from a single synthetic benchmark.



Because 3DMark uses its demanding Port Royal ray tracing scene for the XeSS Feature Test performance gains can be particularly impressive. At 1440p with XeSS in performance mode the benchmark saw a 145% improvement in FPS 109% boost with Balanced mode 81% using Quality mode and 49% with Ultra Quality mode.



The Frame Inspector also showed some good results with XeSS reconstructing the image very well to the point where Intel's Tom Petersen argues the XeSS image actually looks better than native with TAA. Of course you need to take that with a grain of salt and images from a single canned sequence likely won't fully represent real-world gaming experiences.

Image 1 of 2 (Image credit: Intel) (Image credit: Intel)

XeSS SDK and More Than 20 Games in the Works

Intel will be providing an SDK for implementing XeSS in a game engine. The interface and requirements will be very similar to TAA implementations as well as DLSS and FSR 2.0 so it should be a relatively easy addition for any modern graphics engine.



Like TAA FSR 2.0 and DLSS XeSS needs motion vectors along with the current frame and it keeps its own collection of previous frames. These are all fed into the AI network to ultimately generate a good result. XeSS also uses camera jitter to help eliminate aliasing in the scene. (The jitter is on the sub-pixel level so it won't be directly visible to the end user.)



At present Intel has more than 20 games with XeSS planned for release in the coming months. Some of those may fall through the cracks or get delayed but it's at least a decent start for the newcomer. At the same time AMD just announced another eight games that have recently added or will soon be adding FSR 2.0 and Nvidia has well over 100 games shipping with DLSS 2.0 or later. How many game developers will be willing to add all three alternatives which would provide gamers with the choice of the best algorithm? We suspect a lot of games will only support one or two of the possible upscaling options.



XeSS will officially launch when Intel releases its Arc Alchemist GPUs worldwide at some point in the presumably near future. The Arc A380 has effectively launched at this point and Intel has now teased the A750 and A770. Hopefully we'll get to experience XeSS in both MXM and DP4a modes in the not too distant future. At present uptake remains very far behind the AMD and Nvidia competition.

(Image credit: Intel)

Name_4: Intel Arc A380 GPU tested in 50 games "compatibility better than expected for a newcomer"
Text_4:
Intel Arc in large scale practical test

Arc A380 in 50 games and 50 hours of testing.

PC Games Hardware took Intel’s only Arc Alchemist desktop GPU for a large-scale test. Rather than focusing on graphics card to graphics card comparison the GPU was tested for compatibility in 50 titles released from 1999 to 2022.

Intel has some serious issues with the games that do not use modern APIs: Vulkan or DirectX 12. While the company is working around the clock to fix as many bugs as possible and optimize their architecture for older titles the time to launch desktop GPUs is almost over.

Recently Vice Present and GM for Visual Compute Group at Intel Lisa Pearce confirmed the company will work to optimize Arc GPU performance for DX9 and DX11 APIs while DX11 should eventually work as good as DX12 in the future. This process will take time and gamers choosing Arc GPUs should either trust Intel will resolve those issues as soon as possible or just look elsewhere for GPU architecture that works. The good news is that older gamers usually do not require powerful GPUs these days so the choice is plenty.

Intel’s latest driver released on August 19 has eliminated many issues with the GPU compatibility and for its Control panel heavily criticized by reviewers. It is still not perfect and Intel is now fixing known issues and there are many.

Arc A380 in 50 games Source: PC Games Hardware

Some games require a specific Intel driver to work (showing errors on start) but since Intel has branched its Arc Drivers those requirements are simply wrong and games work regardless. Clearly Intel has a lot of work to do with game developers directly and this will take a lot of time. Hopefully with enough resources help from the community and tech reviewers those issues will be resolved soon.

Next month Intel is more than likely to launch its Arc A7 graphics the upper mid-range series that may finally put Intel on performance charts against NVIDIA and AMD most popular GPUs. Unfortunately for Intel both companies will soon introduce new architecture which will strengthen their position even further.

Source: PC Games Hardware
Name_5: Intel Arc A380 tested on 50 games: both old and new includes Crysis
Text_5:
Intel's new Arc A380 graphics card has been tested on 50 games released between 1999 and 2022 with DX9 DX10 DX11 and DX12 games tested.

Intel's new Arc A380 graphics card has been tested in 50 games across a spectrum of titles released between 1999 and 2022 including DirectX 9 DX10 DX11 DX12 OpenGL and Vulkan titles.

2

VIEW GALLERY - 2 IMAGES

The folks over at PC Games Hardware has tested the Intel Arc A380 graphics card which is great to see after hearing Intel Arc GPUs will be using a DirectX 9 to DirectX 12 emulator... as the Arc A-series desktop GPUs have no native DX9 API capabilities. This means we get Arc hardware + Arc software + GPU compatibility in 50 games as a great early look at the Arc GPUs (but not up against AMD and NVIDIA in these results).

As for the games tested the new Intel Arc A380 graphics card ran games flawlessly including Crysis Control Cyberpunk 2077 Elden Ring F1 2022 FEAR (one of my favorites) Red Dead Redemption 2 Stray The Witcher 2 and 3 and many many more. As for the games that didn't work PC Games Hardware notes that Max Payne 2 -- which runs on the older DirectX 8 API -- "doesn't start at all".

Doom Eternal running Vulkan through Steam would freeze at startup sometimes while Half-Life 2 running DX9 through Steam with Transparency AA for Alphatests not working while they note "the rest is fine". The spread of 50 games is a great mix showing that the Intel Arc GPU experience isn't as bad as it could be. It should hopefully radically improve in the weeks and months as they fly by at the same if not at a greater pace... but for now not bad at all.

But we do have to remember: this is on a particular system not all Intel Arc GPU owners will have the same specs games resolutions and APIs being used.

Intel's full ACM-G11 GPU on the TSMC 6nm process node with 8 Xe-Cores or 1024 ALUs with a max GPU clock of 2450MHz. 6GB of GDDR6 is here at 15.5Gbps on a 96-bit memory bus that pumps 186GB/sec of memory bandwidth with a 75W TBP

When it comes to display connectivity the new Intel Arc A380 is pretty awesome: 3 x DisplayPort 2.0 (yeah not DisplayPort 1.4 connectors) and 1 x HDMI 2.0b connector. Intel does provide AIB partners with the ability to add PCONs (Proton Converters) to their Arc GPUs which enables HDMI 2.1 support.

Name: Intercontinental Exchange
Name_1: Stock Market Crash: Expert Compares Current Market to Previous Bubbles
Text_1:
By clicking “Sign Up” you accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy . You can opt-out at any time.

Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app

Sign up to get the inside scoop on today’s biggest stories in markets tech and business — delivered daily. Read preview

The stock market's summer fun may finally be over.

The S&P 500 is down 5.4% since August 16 closing negative for two consecutive weeks now following a 17% rally from mid-June.

Whether or not mid-August was the near-term peak or not the rally in recent months is nothing more than a bull trap according to Bill Smead the founder and CIO of Smead Capital Management.

This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now.

Smead who began his career in 1980 with Drexel Burnham Lambert said in a recent commentary stocks have further downside ahead and that investors remain far too bullish in the face of a Federal Reserve fighting four-decade-high inflation.

Advertisement

"This bear market is designed to punish mass foolishness in everything from FAANG stocks glam tech stocks high price-to-sales up and comers meme stocks SPAC/IPOs cryptocurrencies and the list goes on" Smead said. "We even revived the meme trading in the recent bear market rally. Why are we sure it is a bear market rally? It was led by the same foolishness that triggered the bear market in the first place. Investors are gluttons for punishment in this cycle."

Smead pointed to indications that investor positioning remains relatively bullish despite what has appeared to be a rise in negative sentiment since the start of the year.

The first is a chart from Bank of America showing a lack of the household equity outflows that have occurred in prior downturns. The data is through the end of the first quarter.

Bank of America

According to the same Bank of America note — published on August 9 this year — household equities are the biggest drivers of the market.

Advertisement

Bank of America

Smead also pointed out that household allocations to equities are near their highest levels ever above levels seen during some of the biggest market bubbles in history. Around 40% of household financial assets are currently in equities.

Household allocation to equities is highly correlated to future returns and current levels suggest negative returns for the S&P 500 over the next decade.

Smead Capital Management

High inflation and rapidly rising interest rates will continue to challenge stocks Smead said and further downside will increasingly hurt investor confidence until a higher level of capitulation sets in.

Related stories

"The stock market is likely to shake out the confidence among asset allocators and cause it to match the bearishness expressed in sentiment polls before we hit a meaningful long-term bottom" he said. "Think back to the financial crisis bear market in 2007-2009. There were as many as four significant spikes in bearishness and only the last one marked the end of the bear market."

Advertisement

For the time being investors are better off in commodities and in real estate than the broader stock market Smead said.

Smead's views in context

Stocks fell sharply on Friday after Fed Chair Jerome Powell reiterated the central bank's intention to continue to tighten policy aggressively.

The futures market and some investors have been anticipating a Fed reversal to dovish policy next year. But representatives of the central bank have said that they don't plan to cut rates shortly after raising them aggressively.

Andy Sparks the head of portfolio management research at MSCI told Insider on Friday that he believes the Fed will hold rates higher for a longer period of time before resorting to cutting rates as their credibility is on the line. BlackRock's Rick Rieder expressed a similar opinion last week.

Advertisement

Equity markets tend to be forward-looking discounting mechanisms. When expectations shift so do prices. With the growing consensus and acceptance that the Fed in fact won't back off of their hawkish policies stocks are likely to continue to suffer.

This is because higher interest rates eventually weigh on economic activity and corporate earnings. Signs are already starting to show that the US economy is slowing.

Smead's view that stocks have further downside is shared by a number of Wall Street institutions. Bank of America's top stock strategist Savita Subramanian recently changed her 2022 S&P 500 price target to 3600 which is another 11.5% downside. She also said at the end of 2021 that the index would deliver negative returns over the next decade excluding dividends.

Her counterpart at Morgan Stanley Mike Wilson has a target of 3900 for the index. UBS has also said it's a bad time to buy tech stocks.

Advertisement

RIA Advisors' CIO Lance Roberts said earlier this month that stocks are "detached from reality" and that valuations and earnings expectations have to come down further.

Still many top strategists have S&P 500 price targets above 4000 and most anticipate a "soft landing" scenario where the Fed is able to bring down inflation without sending the US economy into a recession.

The likelihood of that scenario likely depends on how quickly inflation falls from it's current year-over-year level of 8.5%. If it remains sticky the Fed has said they will have the resolve to fight it barring a broad economic downturn. While bringing down inflation is good for the long-term stability of the US economy either scenario — persistently hawkish policy or a recessionary environment — aren't great for the stock market's near-term prospects.
Name_2: This is What a Robotic Explorer Might See When it Reaches Europa's Oceans
Text_2:
For decades evidence has been mounting that beneath the icy crust of Jupiter’s moon Europa a vast ocean exists that could possibly host microbial life. As scientists prepare to send the Europa Clipper mission to orbit the Jupiter system they are trying to learn more about the subsurface ocean and the ice that encompasses the moon.



One way to study Europa is to look at similar environments here on Earth. Scientists say that conditions found under Earth’s Antarctic ice shelf provides an analog to Europa’s subsurface ocean and can help them determine how the moon’s ice shell accretes and grows.

A new study published in the journal Astrobiology looked at a unique phenomenon in the Antarctic ocean called underwater snow. This is where ice floats upwards onto the bottom of the ice shelf and attaches in fluffy-looking mounds. This helps to replenish the ice shelf. The study infers that the same phenomenon is likely true for Jupiter’s moon and may play a role in building and replenishing its exterior ice shell.

According to co-author Donald Blankenship a senior research scientist at the University of Texas at Austin studying this feature on Earth is helping scientists to understand the habitability of Europa.

“We can use Earth to evaluate Europa’s habitability measure the exchange of impurities between the ice and ocean and figure out where water is in the ice” he said in a press release. Blankenship is also the principal investigator for Europa Clipper’s ice penetrating radar instrument which will use radar to peer beneath the ice shell to see if Europa’s ocean could be hospitable to life.

Scientists hope at some point to send a submarine or a swarm of swimming robots to study Europa’s ocean in-situ.

Artist’s concept of a Europa Clipper mission. Credit: NASA/JPL

Previous studies suggest the temperature pressure and salinity of Europa’s ocean nearest to the ice is similar to what is found beneath an ice shelf in Antarctica. The team said that knowing what kind of ice Europa’s shell is made of will also help decipher the salinity and habitability of its ocean.

“When we’re exploring Europa we’re interested in the salinity and composition of the ocean because that’s one of the things that will govern its potential habitability or even the type of life that might live there” said the study’s lead author Natalie Wolfenbarger a graduate student researcher at the University of Texas Institute for Geophysics (UTIG).

Below Europa’s thick icy crust is a massive ocean despite the moon’s great distance from the Sun. If everything else were equal the distance would put Europa well beyond our star’s habitable zone – where conditions are right for liquid water to exist on another world. However Europa’s ocean exists because of tidal heating where the moon is constantly either stretched or compressing as it orbits the massive planet Jupiter in an elliptical orbit. Additionally Europa is also being constantly tugged by fellow moons Io and Ganymede This tidal heating leads to friction within Europa’s core corresponding to heat and ultimately melting the inner ice into what is now Europa’s massive ocean.

Scientists think Europa’s ice shell is 10 to 15 miles (15 to 25 kilometers) thick floating on an ocean 40 to 100 miles (60 to 150 kilometers) deep. So even though Europa is only one-fourth the diameter of Earth scientists think its ocean may contain twice as much water as all of Earth’s oceans combined.

This reprocessed color view of Jupiter’s moon Europa was made from images taken by NASA’s Galileo spacecraft in the late 1990s.

The new study says that the underwater snow is much purer than other kinds of ice which means Europa’s ice shell could be much less salty than previously thought. That’s important for calibrating the radar instrument for Europa Clipper as salt trapped in the ice can affect what and how deep the radar will see into the ice shell. Being able to predict what the ice is made of will help scientists make sense of the data.

“This paper is opening up a whole new batch of possibilities for thinking about ocean worlds and how they work” said Steve Vance a research scientist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) who was not involved in the study. “It sets the stage for how we might prepare for Europa Clipper’s analysis of the ice.”

Read the team’s paper abstract in Astrobiology

Press release from the University of Texas at Austin
Name_3: Power cuts melt Gaza's ice cream stocks as heatwave boosts demand
Text_3:
Lengthy power cuts in the Gaza Strip have melted stocks of ice cream forcing shops to stop selling it just when a heatwave has boosted demand Reuters reports.

With summer temperatures hitting 34 degrees Celsius (93 Fahrenheit) ice cream is a popular and relatively inexpensive treat in Gaza home to 2.3 million people squeezed into a narrow coastal strip between Israel and Egypt.

But owners of several groceries said they had to stop selling it even as a particularly hot summer has increased demand.

“Half of the ice cream melted. What should we do with it? Losses losses” supermarket owner Fouad Awadallah told Reuters.

Gaza would normally require around 500 megawatts of power per day during the summer months of June July and August local officials said. It receives 120 megawatts from Israel while the enclave’s single power plant supplies another 60 megawatts.

The shortfall means residents have only around 11 hours of electricity per day and even that is intermittent.

At the Kazem Ice Cream shop one of the territory’s best known owner Mohammad Abu Shaban said he had to use expensive generators to keep the business going.

“I can’t switch off the generators even for a minute once the electricity goes” he said.

Saly Abu El-Haj 25 travelled 13 kilometres (8 miles) from her Nusseirat refugee camp for a taste of Kazem’s ice cream in Gaza City centre because other shops had stopped selling it.

“If you want to buy something cheaper from a supermarket you won’t find it as owners are afraid ice cream would be wasted once the electricity is off” she said.

Name_4: Nigeria one of Africa’s most viable investment destinations – Adeosun
Text_4:
The President of the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers Oluwole Adeosun tells BABATUNDE TUGBOBO about his career and other issues

You started your career as an accountant. How and when did you venture into stockbroking?

My venture into stockbroking happened as the natural consequence of positions I held during my career. From the financial control department of a bank I was moved to the corporate finance department to provide accounting support for detailed financial analysis of audited financial statements of all the listed companies on the Nigerian Stock Exchange to identify their financing needs upon which corporate finance proposals were generated and marketed to target companies. As an investment banker operating in the primary market as a Securities and Exchange-registered sponsored individual I related well with stockbrokers as parties to primary market offerings and listings on stock exchange. I could have written the examinations then as advised but I was focused on issuing house and advisory functions. There was a policy change by the Central Bank of Nigeria in the last quarter of 1999 which allowed merchants banks to convert to commercial banks based on complaints about the prohibitive cost of funds structure.

Intercontinental Bank was the first merchant bank to switch to commercial banking in the first quarter of 2000. The investment banking corporate finance operations under the merchant bank ceased and could not continue under a commercial banking structure and were consequently transferred to a stockbroking subsidiary called Intercontinental Securities Limited. I was seconded to the company as its first Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer. In line with regulatory requirements I had to qualify as a chartered stockbroker to effectively function in that position. I immediately registered as a student member of the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers in 2001 took lectures and completed the qualifying examinations in two levels in record time which won me a prize in 2002.

What are your roles as the president of the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers?

The President of the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers serves as the Chairman of the institute’s Governing Council. The council is the central policy-making organ of the institute. My role is to serve as the chief servant coordinating the policy-making function and providing leadership inspiration and motivation to the council members management and staff of the institute in order to enable them work to their maximum capacity in a congenial atmosphere that promotes efficiency.

It is also my duty to ensure that the CIS operates in accordance with its enabling statutes and achieves its objective of setting world-class professional standards in the securities and investment space in Nigeria.

How helpful was the demutualisation of the Nigerian Stock Exchange in 2021 to the stock marketing environment?

The demutualisation of The Nigerian Stock Exchange (now NGX Exchange Group) was a major achievement not only for the exchange but the entire capital market community in Nigeria. It was a feat that was meticulously planned and painstakingly executed in a manner that protected the interests of all the key stakeholders including the dealing member firms. Having transformed from a non-profit to a full-fledged public limited liability company with subsidiaries in various areas the exchange has become more business-like in its approach taking steps to eliminate wastages and promoting ventures that enhance the value proposition for its shareholders securities dealers and investors. Infrastructure platforms such as NG Clearing is being set up and people are able to trade on the shares of NGX itself. The technology driving the NGX market is of the highest grade and the market is now better able to compete with the best in the world as an investment destination.

There were fears in some quarters that since ownership and trading rights are now separated new companies aiming to maximise profits and dividends may have little incentive to commit resources for self-regulation. How does the CIS aim to stop that from happening?

The risk of that happening is already minimised. Remember that the NGX is still under the regulation of the Securities and Exchange Commission; so having those separately structured subsidiaries is to foster good corporate governance and efficiency in service delivery. CIS works closely with the NGX as a key partner and most of the key people are our members so we are always in communication to ensure that the public interest is paramount.

One of the issues in the Nigerian Stock Exchange is the failure of companies to adhere to the principles of corporate governance. How best do you think this can be tackled?

Quoted companies are made to sign an undertaking to comply with the post-listing requirements. The requirements are largely on timely disclosure of material information that aid investment decisions devoid of information asymmetry. This is an investor protection mechanism. There is no perfect community in the area of compliance. That is why the exchange ensures that any company that contravenes the post-listing requirements pays a penalty. The exchange has consistently upheld the principles of corporate governance.

In March a bill to replace CIS with a new establishment called Chartered Institute of Securities and Investments passed the second reading stage in the House of Representatives. How did the CIS receive this development?

The development did not come to us as a surprise given the enormous groundwork and consultations that we engaged in. We at the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers thank members of the National Assembly especially the committee on capital market for the progress achieved so far with the bill. The proposed act is for the benefit of the entire capital market not just the CIS and we have conducted far-reaching consultations to carry all relevant and key stakeholders in the market along. The provisions were meticulously couched to ensure that all key segments of the capital market benefit from the new act when it is passed into law.

The Chairman of the House of Reps committee on Capital Market opined that it would widen the scope of the existing institute. How is this so?

That is absolutely correct. CIS was established 30 years ago and people will agree that the capital market and in fact the entire Nigerian economy have changed significantly during that period. The bill is a natural evolution consistent with what has been practised in advanced economies of the world financial system and even nearer home in South Africa.

The capital market is a vehicle for improving the economy of any nation. What role is the CIS playing to see that there is no deficit in professional operators?

The capital market is indeed a significant barometer for the economy of any nation and a particularly important vehicle to achieve significant economic development. The CISIN Bill which we just touched on is one such step CIS is taking; but even before now the institute had taken several key steps to avoid any deficit in the availability of professionally trained and qualified practitioners in the Nigerian capital market. About five years ago we commenced our stand-alone certification scheme which enables interested students to focus on a particular segment of the capital market to specialise and practise in. We have also been running our Diploma in Securities and Investment programme for about a decade. More strategic initiatives and actions will be rolled out in due course.

How viable is the Nigerian economy for potential investors to invest in?

Even as things stand currently Nigeria remains one of the most viable destinations for direct and portfolio investments in Africa. We have by far the largest population. We also have by far the largest concentration of natural resources. Nigeria is a niche market. Those are the key ingredients for non-governmental business concerns to thrive and some giant multinational companies have been coming to set up shop in Nigeria in recent times. However the major challenge is how to leverage the nation’s human and material capital to grow the economy.

What is your career trajectory?

My career trajectory cuts across accounting corporate banking investment banking securities dealings and investments in a career spanning 36 years. I have worked at various financial institutions garnering experience from diverse areas of finance and banking which include the primary and secondary segments of the Nigerian capital market investment banking corporate banking treasury accounting and auditing.

I started my career at First Bank Plc (Port Harcourt Branch) as a youth corps member in 1986. On completion of the national service I started work with Idem Consultants in 1988 and moved to Summit Finance Company Limited later that same year. I made a career switch in October of the same year when I joined Coopers and Lybrand for professional training in accounting and auditing.

I qualified as a chartered accountant in May 1991 and five months later I crossed to the banking industry when I joined the then Nigerian Intercontinental Merchant Bank Limited which later transformed to become Intercontinental Bank Plc. I worked with the Intercontinental Bank Group for 17 years before exiting in 2007 to set up Chartwell Financial Services Group which I have been running for 15 years. During those years of working I was also studying. I obtained additional professional qualifications as a chartered banker chartered stockbroker and chartered tax practitioner.

You trained at Coopers and Lybrand (now Price WaterhouseCoopers). How was the experience and what were your achievements while there?

Coopers and Lybrand was a great workplace where trainees’ professional skills were developed alongside technical accountancy knowledge while studying for the professional ICAN examination those days. Practical experience was gained on audit assignments to the topmost companies in the leading sectors of the economy. Those skills acquired have proven to be a crucial component of well-rounded value added to every position I have held across different organizations I have worked with.

At various times you held different senior positions at Intercontinental Bank between 1991 to 2000— as Head Corporate Finance; Group Head Investment Banking; and Group Head Corporate Banking. Which of those positions did you consider the most taxing?

Each of those positions had their challenges in a nimble organisation such as Intercontinental Group where achievement of one’s targets and budget was key to one’s ratings and placement. By dint of arduous work and God’s grace I was able to consistently overcome the challenges and achieved targets to move on to higher levels of responsibilities.

What were your notable achievements as the CEO of Intercontinental Securities Limited?

Being seconded from the bank to manage its first subsidiary that was mandated by regulators to operate as an autonomous entity was challenging. I had to start on a clean slate with just two members of staff in 2000. It was like setting up a new business entirely but with faith courage and a solid team built under my leadership the company went on to rank in the league of the top three dealing member firms on the Nigerian Stock Exchange. It also became the most profitable subsidiary of the bank with five branches set up across Nigeria and a staff strength of over 150 people at the time of my exit in 2007.

We also sustained the investment banking mandates with primary markets transactions for several companies including the primary listing and initial public offering for Intercontinental Bank Plc.

What was the most difficult decision you took while in that office?

Managing a securities dealings and investment outfit is not a tea party as it requires taking decisions on a daily basis. And such decisions must turn out very well and minimise exposures.

The COVID-19 pandemic took a toll on the economy of the country. How well has the stock market bounced back?

I am immensely proud to affirm that the Nigerian capital market was probably the least affected operationally speaking by the coronavirus pandemic. The reason was that the market was already highly leveraged on technology before the pandemic came.

It is said that no economy can survive during a conflict. How is the insecurity situation in Nigeria affecting the stock market?

Insecurity has a significant negative effect on the capital market for several reasons. First the quoted companies would be negatively impacted with operational costs rising and profits mitigated.

The ease of doing business profile of the country has also been negatively impacted thus discouraging foreign direct investors and other interested entrepreneurs from investing or growing their businesses in the country. It is imperative that the fight against insecurity be made a top priority for the government and the citizenry.

The government placed a ban on the buying and selling of cryptocurrency. As a finance expert what do you make of that decision?

That is the rational decision for now until sovereign states and governments worldwide can have a firm regulatory grip over cryptocurrencies. Last year the Central Bank of Nigeria launched the eNaira and has been working alongside other countries to map out an effective mechanism for regulating the cryptocurrency market. It may not be a ban per se because the trades are done online but just to warn the investors that if they have complaints it will be difficult for the local financial regulators to intervene. It is a work in progress and the Securities and Exchange Commission recently released its guidelines on digital assets.

What informed your decision to start Chartwell Securities Limited?

The decision to start the company with a combined licence as an issuing house and securities dealing/brokerage firm was informed by my core competence in both segments of the capital market as well as fervent belief in the capacity of the Nigerian capital market for further development into the new areas that we have witnessed over the last decade. It is a highly sophisticated and exciting market the impact of which is evident on daily basis in the market statistics published. Having worked for 17 years in the banking sector I felt it was time to move out while the energy and drive were still there.

How do you combine running Chartwell and discharging your duties as President of CIS?

By proper organisation of my schedules and delegation of some responsibilities combining the roles of President of CIS and leadership of my company has been easy and I’m coping well.

Some people believe that there is a need for the privatisation of major sectors of the economy. Do you share that view?

Whether in Nigeria or globally there is ample evidence to show that in a free market economy enterprises that are geared towards making financial profit are best run by private entrepreneurs. In Nigeria the history of state-owned business enterprises has been copiously documented and is quite easy to access. The data points to the fact that the government’s involvement in profit-oriented enterprises has not yielded the desired result in Nigeria so privatisation is a necessity not an option. The crucial factor to consider is the equitability and fairness of the privatisation method adopted. For us in the capital market we usually canvas for public offerings because with that method the average Nigerian that is interested can easily subscribe to those shares through the stock exchange and at a price that is fairly set through the stock exchange’s rigorous and competitive pricing mechanism.

In what ways do you think the government can strengthen the stock market?

Three things come immediately to mind. First the government should support the financial literacy responsibilities of CIS by extending some grants to the institute to enhance the programme. Second the CBN and the banking system should extend liquidity to securities dealing firms for trading purposes which will help stabilise the market. The same request is made to the various pension funds in the country to invest more in the equities market as is being done in advanced economies. Third the government should have more engagements and consultations with stockbrokers during policy making budgeting and foreign relations. The benefits are mutual. The government also needs the capital market to be strong to achieve a stronger economy and faster GDP growth.

Tell us about your educational background.

I attended Loyola College Ibadan Oyo State between September 1977 and June 1982. I hold a Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration from the University of Ilorin and an MBA in Finance and Banking from the University of Lagos.

I qualified as a chartered accountant in May 1991. I later qualified as a chartered banker and chartered stockbroker while working with Intercontinental Bank and Intercontinental Securities Limited respectively. I am a fellow of the major professional institutes in Nigeria’s financial services sector including the Chartered Institute of Stockbrokers Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nigeria Chartered Institute of Bankers of Nigeria Chartered Institute of Taxation of Nigeria Institute of Credit Administration Institute of Directors.

Did your parents influence your choice of career?

Not at all. I chose what I wanted to do which was banking based on my early exposure to the banking environment as a secondary school student that frequently went to the bank to lodge daily sales proceeds of my mother’s pharmacy business in the then Standard Bank of Nigeria now First Bank of Nigeria. During my university days I also had the opportunity of doing vacation jobs in First Bank and Union Bank and that exposed me further to the banking sector and defined my career path.

What do you consider the greatest lesson life has taught you?

To have implicit trust and faith in God and to stay focused on my goals.

What do you consider to be the most memorable moment of your life?

There have been several memorable moments in my life across board such as passing examinations winning awards and professional elevations.

However one of the most memorable moments was in 2017 when as the chairman of my alumni’s set at Loyola College we gave out scholarships to 10 indigent but brilliant students to enable them progress from junior secondary school to senior secondary school and to give them a better chance in life. On the day of the award which coincided with the set’s 35th year of graduating from the school in 1982. The parents of the indigent students were in attendance and one could see the joy and relief on their faces because of the impact of our initiatives that brought smiles to their faces. It brought good feelings about what can be done to make impact in other people’s lives.

Did you at any point in your career feel like quitting?

There have been high and low points in my career over the years. As an optimist quitting was never an option. Rather I chose to face the issues headlong as they cropped up. The most challenging moment was during the global financial crisis of 2008 when I had just completed the registration requirements for Chartwell Securities Limited and started the business with a significant market portfolio. Six weeks later the global meltdown set in with a consistent decline in asset values and shareholders’ funds for the next three years till 2011 when the markets achieved some stability and a subsequent turnaround in 2014. Those were some harrowing moments in my career.

Many youths want to travel out of the country to seek greener pastures. What advice do you have for them?

Those who migrated to other countries two or three decades ago are returning home now to the same country they left. The thrust of our work at CIS is to create adequate opportunities career-wise for our youths in a manner that every young Nigerian that is intellectually endowed can access conveniently. That is the reason we have in addition to our professional exams the Diploma in Securities and Investment programme as well as the stand-alone certification scheme. These are steps we are continually taking to give our youths adequate professional opportunities at home which hopefully should discourage the urge to migrate.

How impactful was your programme at the New York Institute of Finance on your career?

United States Capital Markets 1 and 2 is the flagship programme of the prestigious New York Institute of Finance that attracts participants from all over the world to learn from the base of capitalism on which the capital market stands. The programme provided much-needed exposure to the totality of products and services in the market far beyond the level of the Nigerian market then. The knowledge and skill acquired have enabled me and my colleagues to prepare for the evolving market developments in our environment over the years. There is a need for the Federal Government and the sub-nationals to use more of the structured product offerings of the capital market to fund major projects in infrastructure delivery that will impact more on the lives of the citizens with significant multiplier effects on the economy.

How and where did you meet your wife?

I met her in Lagos while on a visit to my cousin who was her flatmate then as young graduates working and living together. We got talking over several visits thereafter and I realised that her values complimented mine in many ways so I took it on from there.

What endeared you to her?

She is well-read in her field and knowledgeable beautiful inwardly and outwardly simple in her ways a lover of God and always willing to help people.

How do you spend quality time as a couple?

We arrange vacations in getaway locations to relax reflect and project on our union. Our children are all grown up now and independent so we can afford to be alone together which is different from what it used to be in the past when the kids were still growing.

Who is your role model?

My role model (in life) is Pastor Enoch Adeoye who influenced my outlook in terms of simplicity humility quest for holiness and heavenly focus which guide my everyday decisions.

On the professional front my role model was my former boss and mentor Dr Erastus Akingbola who I believe to be one of the best managers of men and resources. He shows interest in one’s life. He also continually mentions fresh challenges for one to display one’s knowledge and skills.

What is your favourite food?

Pounded yam with vegetables is my favourite for lunch while bread with eggs my preferred option for breakfast.

How do you unwind?

I watch sports and documentaries. I also enjoy reading novels.

How do you like to dress?

My style is driven by my routine which is mostly formal Monday through to Friday as I engage in several meetings in and out of the office.

Saturday affords me the opportunity of wearing native attire and simple informal clothing.

On Sundays as a minister of the Gospel my dressing is strictly formal and informal for post-church service for social engagements.
Name_5: RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 Review
Text_5:
With Ruby seeming to succumb to the Nightmare’s influence things were getting dark for the team. But there may yet be some hope to wake Weiss from her slumber. With the team separated it’ll take a lot of determination if they are to salvage a win out of their current situation in RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9. RWBY: Ice Queendom is an action/fantasy anime produced by Shaft.

This week’s episode opens with Ruby having a heart-to-heart talk in her dream with the real Weiss rather than the negative Weiss the team has been struggling against. I enjoyed this opening as it delivers a lot of heart and the exchange feels like it is the sort of moment that is riddled with clues that will come to reveal themselves in the coming episodes.

From this intriguing opening RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 steadily picks up steam as it brings its scattered cast back up to speed with the evolving situation. This episode’s energy managed to hold onto my attention far better than previous entries. It balances conversation with action nicely and even takes a moment to deliver a fairly haunting musical number that manages to create a nice contrast in the tone of the episode without feeling like it is slowing down the episode’s pace. Admittedly the moment was the last thing I expected. But perhaps that is part of what helps it work so well.

With all the narrative elements about to collide again it feels like the story is finally going to deliver some forward momentum for this leg of its journey. While I hope this is the case I can’t help but worry there will be one more stall out before the series truly heads into its endgame.

The only spot where RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 struggles is in a couple of failures on the part of its cast to connect some fairly apparent dots. While a lot is going on and some missed clues are understandable there is one major element to the situation that is so obvious there is no way the characters shouldn’t have picked up on it yet.

While much of the scenery is what we have seen before RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 manages to deliver some new visual elements to its story that land wonderfully. Some surreal moments provide a much-needed break-up in the story’s familiarity and the aforementioned musical number receives much of its power from the visuals accompanying the moment.

When all is said and done RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 does a good job of righting what had been a floundering narrative over the last handful of episodes. As long as future installments can continue to build off of the moment this episode sets in motion this series could deliver a final stretch as strong as its opening chapters.

RWBY: Ice Queendom Episode 9 is streaming now on Crunchyroll.

Name_2: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. ...
Text_2:
Reported Revenue: $2.9 billion a decrease of 4% year-over-year surpassing estimates of $2.780 billion.

Net Income: $61 million significantly below the estimated net income of $220.27 million.

Earnings Per Share (EPS): Reported at $0.23 significantly below the estimated $0.87.

Operating EBITDA: Adjusted operating EBITDA was $578 million showing a robust 20% increase from the previous year on a comparable basis.

Free Cash Flow: Ended the quarter with a negative $19 million reflecting capital expenditures subtracted from operational cash flow.

Debt Leverage: Net debt to credit adjusted EBITDA ratio stood at 4.4x at the end of the quarter.

Future Outlook: Company expects full-year results to trend towards the higher end of the previously announced guidance with sales expected between $10.8 billion and $11.1 billion and adjusted operating EBITDA between $1.9 billion and $2.1 billion.

On May 6 2024 International Flavors & Fragrances Inc (NYSE:IFF) disclosed its financial outcomes for the first quarter ending March 31 2024 through an 8-K filing. The report presented a nuanced financial landscape marked by strategic divestitures and robust segment performance albeit with a slight decline in overall revenue.

International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) Q1 2024 Earnings: Navigating Market Challenges with Strategic Divestitures and Solid Segment Growth

Company Overview

International Flavors & Fragrances stands as a global leader in the production of specialty ingredients used across diverse industries including food beverage personal care and pharmaceuticals. The company's expertise in creating unique flavor and fragrance solutions drives its operations segmented into Nourish Health & Biosciences and Scent among others.

Financial Performance Highlights

The company reported a decrease in net sales to $2.9 billion down by 4% from the previous year yet surpassed the estimated revenue of $2780.10 million. This decline was partially offset by a notable increase in adjusted operating EBITDA which rose by 20% on a comparable basis reaching $578 million. The adjusted EPS excluding amortization stood at $1.13 significantly higher than the anticipated $0.87 showcasing a resilient operational performance despite market volatilities.

Segment-Specific Achievements

The Scent segment exhibited remarkable growth with a 16% increase in currency-neutral sales driven by consumer fragrance and fine fragrance sectors. The Health & Biosciences segment also showed a strong performance with a 21% improvement in adjusted operating EBITDA attributed to advancements in cultures and food enzymes. Conversely the Nourish segment faced challenges though it managed a 3% growth in currency-neutral sales.

Story continues

Strategic Movements and Financial Guidance

Amidst these financial dynamics IFF has strategically divested its Pharma Solutions and Cosmetic Ingredients businesses aligning with its portfolio optimization strategy. These decisions are pivotal in strengthening the company's capital structure and improving its debt leverage ratio. Looking forward IFF has adjusted its 2024 full-year guidance towards the higher end of its sales and adjusted operating EBITDA projections indicating a positive outlook for the upcoming periods.

Operational and Market Challenges

Despite the positive segment growth IFF faces ongoing challenges including market volatility and the impacts of strategic divestitures on its business model. The company's ability to navigate these complexities while maintaining growth in key segments will be crucial for sustained financial health.

Conclusion

International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (NYSE:IFF)'s first quarter of 2024 reflects a strategic adaptation to market demands and operational challenges. With solid growth in key business segments and proactive portfolio adjustments IFF is poised to continue its leadership in the specialty ingredients market albeit mindful of the unpredictable economic landscape ahead.

Name_4: Taste of Fairfield highlights international flavors with restaurant rewards app
Text_4:
FAIRFIELD Ohio — With dozens of restaurants closing across Ohio last year communities are getting creative to entice diners to support mom-and-pop restaurants: from food festivals to rewards programs. In Butler County’s Fairfield they’re supporting a diverse group of restaurants with an electronic passport and prizes.

What You Need To Know Flavors of Fairfield features an app that lets you track visits to international restaurants in the city



You can win a fun medal and even a $1000 gift card at Fairfield's Jungle Jim's International Market



Flavors of Fairfield is a joint effort between the city of Fairfield Travel Butler County and Jungle Jim's

Flavors of Fairfield features a passport app to track your travels trying new restaurants. The city features a variety of cuisines from Dominican Dishes at Mofongo City to Vietnamese Flavors at Pho district Cincy.

“You can get everything from Nepalese food different Indian restaurants Colombian food all kinds of South American options all kinds of things you would not expect in Ohio let alone Fairfield Ohio” said Mark Borison a podcaster based at Jungle Jim’s International Market another place that attracts foodies to Fairfield.

If you check in at four restaurants you can head to the market and meet up with Borison who will give you a medal designed to look like a spork.

“I’ll also probably give you a snack” Borison said.

Eight or more restaurant check-ins will enter you to win the $1000 gift card and some other prizes.

His store has more than three times the items than there are residents in Fairfield a town of fewer than 50000 people.

“What’s so fun about this: there’s so many restaurants you can try in Fairfield you can expand your horizons and if you win the Jungle Jim’s gift card you don’t have to just go to the restaurants you can make those flavors at home now too” he said.

Flavors of Fairfield is a collaboration between the city of Fairfield Travel Butler County and Jungle Jim’s. For more information you can go to their website.
